front.title: Mitigation of Privacy Concerns in DHCPv6

abstract.t: discusses various privacy considerations in DHCPv6. This draft explores several migitation techniques. This draft is expected to evolve significantly over time, but the ultimate goal is to standardize mitigation techniques the DHC working group considers useful.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: DHCPv6 is a protocol that is used to provide addressing and configuration information to IPv6 hosts. The DHCPv6 protocol uses several identifiers that could become a source for gleaning additional information about the IPv6 host. This information may include device type, operating system information, location(s) that the device may have previously visited, etc. This document discusses the various identifiers used by DHCPv6 and the potential privacy issues .
Future works may propose protocol changes to fix the privacy issues that have been analyzed in this document. It is out of scope for this document.

Editor notes: for now, the document is mainly considering the privacy of DHCPv6 client. The privacy of DHCPv6 server and relay agent are considered less important because they are open for public services. However, this may be a subject to change if further study shows opposite result.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: This section clarifies the terminology used throughout this document.

Stable identifier - any property disclosed by a DHCPv6 client that does not change over time or changes very infrequently and is unique for said client in a given context. Examples include MAC address, client-id that does not change or a hostname. Stable identifier may or may not be globally unique.

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in . When these words are not in ALL CAPS (such as "should" or "Should"), they have their usual English meanings, and are not to be interpreted as key words.

section.title: Not disclose the desire for privacy
section.t: Naive approach to privacy would be to disclose the desire to protect one's privacy, for example by sending requests for temporary addresses or defining a new type of temporary DUID that would be changing over time. This leads to a logical fallacy. It has to be assumed that the network operator (or other entities that have access to the operator's network) is actively participating in surveillance and anti-privacy, willingly or not. By simply relealing the desire for privacy, an operator could counter-react by triggering additional surveillance or monitoring mechanisms. Therefore is more preferable to not disclose one's preference for privacy.
This fact has important implications. In particular, all mitigation techniques should be indistinguishable from regular client behaviors, if possible.

section.title: Randomized DUID
section.t: One of the primary privacy concerns is that a client is disclosing a stable itentifier that can be use for tracking and behavior profiling. The most obvious way of disclosing client's MAC/hardware address in DHCPv6 is to use DUID type LLT (link-layer with time) or LL (link-layer). Another DUID type - UUID - is also bad in this regards, as its the UUID may contain additional information about the device it is tied to.
Discussion: As stated in , the desire for privacy should not be explicitly advertised. Therefore a new DUID type is not recommended here.

PROPOSAL: The clients willing to protect its privacy SHOULD generate a new randomized DUID-LLT every time they attach to a new link or detect a possible link change event. Details are left up to implementors, but several factors should be taken into consideration. Duid type SHOULD be set to 1 (DUID-LLT). Hardware type SHOULD be set appropriately to the hardware type. Time MAY be set to current time, but this will reveal the fact that the DUID is new. Implementors interested in hiding that fact MAY use past time stamp. For example a random timestamp in the last year seems like a good value. In the most common cases the link-layer address is based on MAC. The first three bytes are OUI (Organizationally Unique Identifier) that is expected to have a value assigned to a real organization. See for currently assigned values. Using a value that is unassinged may disclose the fact that a DUID is randomized. Using a value that belongs to a third party may have legal implications.

section.title: Do not send Confirm
section.t: The states that a client must send Confirm message when link attachement may have changed. While moving to a different location, legacy clients send Confirm message with its old address, thus revealing previous location.
PROPOSAL: Clients interested in protecting their privacy SHOULD NOT send Confirm.

section.title: Obtaining temporary addresses
section.t: defines special container (IA_TA) for requesting temporary addresses. This is a good mechanism in principle, but there are a number of issues associated with it. First, this is not widely used feature, so clients depending solely on temporary addresses may lock themselves out of service. Second, the does not specify renewal mechanisms for temporary addresses. Therefore support for renewing temporary addresses may vary between server implementations, including not being supported at all. Finally, by using temporary addresses, a client reveals its desire to be anonymous or at least being privacy conscious. If network operator participates in counter-privacy operation, he may conduct actions to defeat the purpose of using temporary addresses.

PROPOSAL: Clients interested in increasing their privacy SHOULD not use IA_TA. They should send IA_NA with a randomized IAID. This, along with the mitigation technique discussed in , will ensure that a client will get a new address that can be renewed, so can be used as long as needed. To get a new address, it can send Request message with a new randomized IAID before releasing the other one. This will cause the server to assign a new address, as it still has a valid lease for the old IAID value. Once a new address is assigned, the one using old IAID value can be released safely, using Release message.

This proposal may not work if the server enforces specific policies, e.g. only one address per client. If client does not succeed in receiving a second address using a new IAID, it may release the first one (using an old IAID) and then retry asking for a new address.
From the Operating System perspective, addresses obtained using this technique SHOULD be treated as temporary as specified in .

section.title: Do not request FQDN
section.t: A typical client uses FQDN option, defined in to negotiate with a server the DNS entries that should be updated. In the process, the client typically reveals its hostname and possibly its home domain. Server, depending on configured policies, may accept or override the name with network specific information.

PROPOSAL: Client SHOULD avoid disclosing its hostname as it may contain personally identifiers (e.g. "Tomek's laptop") and even it doesn't, it may still be used for tracking. Therefore a client SHOULD not send FQDN option at all. This eliminate that velue of information leakage, but has a disavantage of not having a resolvable DNS name. Should DNS name be useful, a client SHOULD send a randomly generated hostname, consisting of a single label. The server is expected to append domain name and return FQDN to the client. Client can then use that value as its temporary hostname that will be discarded once its location changes or the client choses to assume a new identity.

section.title: Options order matters
section.t: A DHCPv6 client may reveal other types of information, besides unique identifiers. There are many ways a DHCPv6 client can conduct certain actions. The specifics can be used to fingerprint the client. This will not reveal the identity of a client, but may give additional information, e.g. device type, vendor type or OS type and in some cases specific version.
One specific method used for fingerprinting is the order in which options are included in the message. Another related is the order of option codes included in ORO (Option Request Option).
PROPOSAL: The client willing to protect its privacy SHOULD randomize options order before sending any DHCPv6 message. Such a client SHOULD also randomly shuffle the option codes order in ORO.

section.title: Anonymous Information-Request
section.t: According to , a DHCPv6 client typically includes its client identifier in most of the messages it sends. There is one exception, however. Client is allowed to omit its client identifier when sending Information-Request.

PROPOSAL: When using stateless DHCPv6, clients willing to protect their privacy SHOULD not include client identifiers in their Information-Request messages. This will prevent the server from specifying client-specific options if it is configured to do so, but that's the point of protecting one's privacy.
